title: Population in wild sheep with 5 answer options 4

content.question: In the graphs below, the solid line represents the original population. The dotted line on which graph best represents the sheep population that would have resulted from a sustained increase in the primary productivity of the environment?

choices.label: For each graph A through E, the graph is identical to the original population of sheep in the previous graph. The horizontal axis is labeled year from 1820 to 1940 with tick marks in increments of ten, and the vertical axis labeled number of sheep in thousands from zero to two thousand five hundred with tick marks in increments of 500. The population curve starts at zero in 1820, increases slowly then increases rapidly to two point two five million by 1850. After 1850 the population curve fluctuates between two point two five million and one point two five million.  A)The dotted line overlaps the solid line until 1850, except that it reaches up to three million sheep, and then follows a similar pattern of fluctuation at a higher population level, between two and three million.

For each graph A through E, the graph is identical to the original population of sheep in the previous graph. The horizontal axis is labeled year from 1820 to 1940 with tick marks in increments of ten, and the vertical axis labeled number of sheep in thousands from zero to two thousand five hundred with tick marks in increments of 500. The population curve starts at zero in 1820, increases slowly then increases rapidly to two point two five million by 1850. After 1850 the population curve fluctuates between two point two five million and one point two five million.  B)The dotted line overlaps the solid line until 1850, except that it peaks at two point seven five million sheep, and then decreases rapidly to zero in 1860.

For each graph A through E, the graph is identical to the original population of sheep in the previous graph. The horizontal axis is labeled year from 1820 to 1940 with tick marks in increments of ten, and the vertical axis labeled number of sheep in thousands from zero to two thousand five hundred with tick marks in increments of 500. The population curve starts at zero in 1820, increases slowly then increases rapidly to two point two five million by 1850. After 1850 the population curve fluctuates between two point two five million and one point two five million.  C) The dotted line starts at zero in 1820, increases slowly to five hundred thousand in 1830, and then continues vertically to two point five million by 1831.

For each graph A through E, the graph is identical to the original population of sheep in the previous graph. The horizontal axis is labeled year from 1820 to 1940 with tick marks in increments of ten, and the vertical axis labeled number of sheep in thousands from zero to two thousand five hundred with tick marks in increments of 500. The population curve starts at zero in 1820, increases slowly then increases rapidly to two point two five million by 1850. After 1850 the population curve fluctuates between two point two five million and one point two five million.  D) The dotted line overlaps the solid line until 1850, and then decreases to seven hundred fifty thousand sheep in 1875, increases to two point five million sheep in 1900, decreases again to one million sheep in 1920, and increases to two point two five million in 1940.

For each graph A through E, the graph is identical to the original population of sheep in the previous graph. The horizontal axis is labeled year from 1820 to 1940 with tick marks in increments of ten, and the vertical axis labeled number of sheep in thousands from zero to two thousand five hundred with tick marks in increments of 500. The population curve starts at zero in 1820, increases slowly then increases rapidly to two point two five million by 1850. After 1850 the population curve fluctuates between two point two five million and one point two five million.  E) The dotted line starts at zero in 1820, increases at a constant rate to one point two five million sheep in 1850 where it flattens out and remains constant.

content.answer: For each graph A through E, the graph is identical to the original population of sheep in the previous graph. The horizontal axis is labeled year from 1820 to 1940 with tick marks in increments of ten, and the vertical axis labeled number of sheep in thousands from zero to two thousand five hundred with tick marks in increments of 500. The population curve starts at zero in 1820, increases slowly then increases rapidly to two point two five million by 1850. After 1850 the population curve fluctuates between two point two five million and one point two five million.  A)The dotted line overlaps the solid line until 1850, except that it reaches up to three million sheep, and then follows a similar pattern of fluctuation at a higher population level, between two and three million.

skill.text: 6.E: Predict the causes or effects of a change in, or disruption to, one or more components in a biological system.
